sen.j: 成願寺（じょうがんじ）は、滋賀県東近江市（旧八日市市）小脇町にある天台宗の寺院。
sen.e: Jogan-ji Temple is a Tendai sect temple in Owaki-cho, Higashiomi City (former Yokaichi City), Shiga prefecture.
Jogan-ji Temple is a Tendai sect temple in Owaki-cho, Higashiomi City (former Yokaichi City), Shiga Prefecture.
sen.cmt: Prefecture(大文字）に変更しました。
sen.e: Jogan-ji Temple is a Tendai sect temple in Owaki-cho, Higashiomi City (former Yokaichi City), Shiga Prefecture.
The sango (the name of a group of Buddhist temples to which the temple belongs) is 赤神山.
The sango (literally "mountain name," the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple) is 赤神山.
sen.cmt: 山号の説明を変更しました。赤神山の読み方不明です。
sen.e: The sango (literally "mountain name," the title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple) is 赤神山.
The honzon (principal image of Buddha) is Yakushi Nyorai (the Healing Buddha).
The honzon (principal image of Buddha) is Yakushi Nyorai (the Healing Buddha).
The honzon (principal image of Buddha) is Yakushi Nyorai (the Healing Buddha).
History
History
History

sen.j: この寺は、寺伝によれば799年（延暦18年）日本天台宗の祖最澄が開いたと伝えられ、かつては多くの塔頭を有する大寺であったという。
sen.e: The temple history says that this temple was founded in 799 by Saicho, the originator of the Tendai sect in Japan, and used to be a huge temple which possessed many tacchu (minor temple).
The temple's biography says that this temple was founded in 799 by Saicho, the originator of the Tendai sect in Japan, and used to be a huge temple which possessed many tacchu (minor temple).
sen.cmt: temple historyをtemple's biographyに変更しました。
sen.e: The temple's biography says that this temple was founded in 799 by Saicho, the originator of the Tendai sect in Japan, and used to be a huge temple which possessed many tacchu (minor temple).

sen.j: 戦国時代 (日本)には蒲生氏、江戸時代には江戸幕府の帰依を得、寺領などを寄進された。
sen.e: In the Sengoku period (period of warring states), it was embraced by GAMO clan, and in the Edo period embraced by Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) with jiryo (temple estate) and so forth being donated.

In the Sengoku period (period of warring states), it was embraced by the GAMO clan, and in the Edo period embraced by Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) with jiryo (temple estate) and so forth being donated.
sen.cmt: 蒲生氏にtheを加えました。
sen.e: In the Sengoku period (period of warring states), it was embraced by the GAMO clan, and in the Edo period embraced by Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) with jiryo (temple estate) and so forth being donated.
